* Burmah Oil P.L.C., Swindon, England, will spend $46 million to purchase Chem-Trend Inc., a supplier of metalworking fluids and lubricants based near Detroit.
* Computer Associates International Inc., Garden City, L.I., is combining various operations to create a division for new software products and services.
* Continental Health Affiliates Inc., Englewood Cliffs, N.J., has increased its offer for Healthdyne Inc. by $1 a share, to $7. If successful, the deal will be worth $105 million.
* W. R. Grace & Co. said it would record a pretax gain of $55 million from the sale of its Bermans Specialty Stores to Melville Corp.

* MGM/UA Communications Co., Beverly Hills, Calif., signed a licensing agreement valued at more than $100 million that will give British Broadcasting Corp. and British Satellite Broadcasting the right to run certain MGM/UA feature films, television series and movies of the week.
* Maxicare Health Plans Inc., Los Angeles, has hired Goldman, Sachs & Co. to act as financial advisers for a capital restructuring that it expects to announce in December.

* Neoax Inc., Cleveland, announced a leveraged recapitalization under which it would sell five truckload carriers that it recently acquired in a merger with IU International Corp. Landstar System Inc. will buy the carriers for $94 million in cash plus common stock and $16 million of 7.5 percent preferred stock.

* Pennwalt Corp., Philadelphia, announced that it would open a plant in Thorofare, N.J., in early 1989 to produce the gas HCFC 142b, an alternative to chlorofluorocarbons, which destroy the earth's ozone layer.
